questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because she is seeing things that she knows are not there. Sometimes she sees a dog in her kitchen and at other times she sees a stranger in her garden, both of which no one else can see. She also reports a lack of motivation to do daily tasks for the past week. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with Parkinson disease and was started on levodopa and carbidopa. Her younger brother has schizophrenia. The patient also takes levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. She used to drink a bottle of wine every day, but she stopped drinking alcohol 2 months ago. Neurologic examination shows a mild resting tremor of the hands and bradykinesia. Her thought process is organized and logical. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Levodopa (L-DOPA), a dopamine precursor, is the most effective medication for controlling the motor symptoms of Parkinson disease. Primary effects of L-DOPA are achieved by stimulating D2-receptors in the substantia nigra and striatum. However, overstimulation of D2-receptors by levodopa may also induce psychosis and hallucinations (usually visual). The risk for developing psychiatric symptoms increases with age, other psychiatric conditions, long duration of levodopa treatment, and high doses. Since this patient has been taking levodopa for 3 years and is elderly, her symptoms are most likely the result of levodopa therapy.

Other adverse effects of L-DOPA therapy include dizziness, somnolence or insomnia, anxiety, and aggressive behavior.
Image Description:

Dopamine agonists (e.g., ropinirole, bromocriptine) bind to the dopamine receptor, mimicking the action of dopamine.

DOPA-Decarboxylase (DDC) inhibitors (e.g., carbidopa) decrease the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, which results in reduced peripheral side-effects of L-DOPA. These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore do not reduce dopamine production in the brain nor do they have central side-effects.

Dopamine precursors (e.g., L-DOPA) are converted by DOPA decarboxylase at the presynaptic neuron resulting in direct dopaminergic effects (especially in D2 receptors).

COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone, tolcapone) inhibits central (tolcapone) or peripheral (entacapone) catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) resulting in the reduced metabolization of dopamine, increase in dopamine effects, a decreased demand for L-DOPA, and a longer therapeutic effect with each dose.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.

Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.

NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

B) INCORRECT:

Alcohol withdrawal occurs in individuals with alcohol use disorder shortly after a complete cessation of alcohol consumption (i.e., within 24 hours). Common clinical manifestations are mild (e.g., gastrointestinal symptoms, headache, insomnia) but more severe findings (e.g., seizure, hallucinations, impaired consciousness) may also develop. Although this patient's visual hallucinations are similar to those seen in alcoholic hallucinosis and alcohol withdrawal delirium, she has not consumed alcohol for 2 months; alcohol withdrawal cannot be the cause of her symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

The clinical features of schizophrenia can be categorized according to positive symptoms of psychosis and negative symptoms of psychosis. Although this patient has an increased risk (∼ 12%) of developing schizophrenia because her brother is affected, she lacks other expected symptoms (e.g., disorganized thought process, alogia). Moreover, symptom onset at the patient's age would also be very unusual since schizophrenia is typically diagnosed in the late 20s in women.

D) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder (MDD) can sometimes be associated with psychotic symptoms. In addition to the clinical features of MDD, patients may present with delusions and hallucinations, which are often auditory but can also be visual or tactile. Although this patient has hallucinations and recently noted a lack of motivation, she does not meet the criteria for a diagnosis of MDD.

E) INCORRECT:

Poorly controlled hypothyroidism, especially in older patients, may manifest with features similar to dementia, including impaired memory and concentration. Although hallucinations may occur, they are rare and usually accompanied by psychotic symptoms, such as paranoia and thought disorders. This patient does not have any expected signs or symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain) and has isolated hallucinations, making thyroid dysfunction unlikely.
questions.hint: While hallucinations may be caused by dysregulation of a variety of neurotransmitters, this patient's symptoms are most likely due to an activation of dopamine D2-receptors.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of gradually worsening rhythmic movements of his right hand for the past 5 months. His symptoms worsen when he is in a meeting and he is concerned that people are noticing it. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient recalls that his father developed bobbing of the head at an older age. He takes no medications. Neurologic examination shows tremor of the right hand with a frequency of approximately 5 Hz when the limbs are relaxed. When the patient is asked to move his arm the tremor decreases. There is reduced arm swing while walking. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Donepezil is a cholinesterase inhibitor used for the treatment of dementia, such as Alzheimer disease, vascular dementia, and frontotemporal dementia. In patients with PD, donepezil is used as an adjunctive treatment for symptoms of dementia. This patient shows no signs of cognitive impairment and has only recently begun noticing neurologic deficits. Dementia is typically a symptom of late-stage PD.

B) CORRECT:

Trihexyphenidyl is a muscarinic antagonist that reduces cholinergic activity in the CNS. Initial monotherapy with an anticholinergic (e.g., trihexyphenidyl, benztropine, biperiden) can be considered in patients with PD who are ≤ 65 years of age if the main symptom is resting tremor and there is no evidence of cognitive impairment, significant bradykinesia, or gait disturbance. Alternative pharmacotherapy for patients with PD who are ≤ 65 years of age includes nonergot dopamine agonists, MAO-B inhibitors, COMT inhibitors, and/or levodopa/carbidopa. Anticholinergics should be avoided in patients > 65 years of age (particularly those with dementia) because they may worsen psychiatric symptoms and cause urinary retention.

See “Common types of tremors” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Clonazepam can be used to treat patients with orthostatic tremor, a condition with an average onset of ∼ 60 years of age. Typical clinical features of orthostatic tremor are triggered by longer periods of standing and include leg tremors as well as a sensation of instability. However, the condition only affects the legs and would not be the cause of this patient's hand tremor or reduced arm swing.

D) INCORRECT:

Topiramate is second-line treatment of benign essential tremor. This patient likely has a family history of essential tremor (his father developed head bobbing at an older age). However, unlike the asymmetric resting tremor seen in this patient, essential tremor is symmetrical, worsens with voluntary movements, and resolves completely at rest.

E) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is used to treat hyperthyroidism. Although patients with hyperthyroidism can also present with a tremor that increases with stress, as in this patient, the tremor is usually symmetric and occurs while holding a position against gravity (e.g., extending arms in front of the body). It would also not explain this patient's bradykinesia.

F) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is a first-line treatment of benign essential tremor. This patient likely has a family history of essential tremor (his father developed head bobbing at an older age). However, unlike the asymmetric resting tremor seen in this patient, essential tremor is symmetrical, worsens with voluntary movements, and resolves completely at rest.
questions.hint: A unilateral resting tremor with a frequency of 4–6 Hz that worsens with stress and improves with voluntary movements, as well as signs of mild bradykinesia (decreased arm swing), are features consistent with Parkinson disease (PD).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of gradual onset of bilateral ankle swelling over the past month. He also noticed reddish blotches of skin around his ankles. Five weeks ago, he came to the physician with difficulty walking and a resting tremor. He was diagnosed with Parkinson disease and started on medication. He has a history of hypertension and his antihypertensive medications were also adjusted. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 64/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 124/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral 2+ edema in the ankles. There is purple-red discoloration on the lower legs in a reticular pattern. Neurologic examination shows resting tremor in both hands and bilateral cogwheel rigidity in the elbows. Which of the following pharmacotherapies is the most likely cause of this patient's edema?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Levodopa is a dopamine precursor that is administered with carbidopa, which prevents its degradation. This combination drug is a first-line treatment for Parkinson patients > 65 years of age. Levodopa can cause gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting), orthostatic hypotension, and induce psychotic symptoms. However, ankle edema and livedo reticularis are not commonly seen with the use of these drugs.

B) INCORRECT:

Selegiline is an MAO-B inhibitor that can be used as an alternative to levodopa or dopamine agonists to treat Parkinson patients with mild symptoms, or it can be taken in combination with levodopa to reduce motor fluctuations. Common side effects of selegiline include nausea, headache, and insomnia. In older patients, selegiline can also precipitate confusion. Ankle edema and livedo reticularis are not commonly seen with the use of this drug.

C) INCORRECT:

Entacapone is a COMT inhibitor used as an adjunct to levodopa therapy. It increases the effectiveness of levodopa by preventing its peripheral breakdown. The most common side effects of COMT inhibitors are nausea and dyskinesia. Peripheral edema and livedo reticularis are not commonly seen with COMT inhibitors.

D) INCORRECT:

Losartan can be used to treat hypertension, especially in patients with comorbid diabetes who cannot tolerate an ACE inhibitor. It can cause hyperkalemia and also rarely angioedema, albeit at lower rates than ACE inhibitors. However, peripheral edema and livedo reticularis are not associated with losartan.

E) CORRECT:

Amantadine is a weak NMDA receptor antagonist that can improve motor symptoms (tremor, rigidity, akinesia) in patients with mild forms of Parkinson disease, or it can be combined with levodopa to reduce dyskinesia in patients with advanced disease. Livedo reticularis and peripheral edema, which are seen in this patient, occur as adverse effects in up to 5% of patients who take amantadine.

See “Overview of antiparkinson drugs” table.

Lisinopril is a first-line agent for hypertension in patients with comorbid diabetes. Cough and hyperkalemia are common side effects. Rarely, this drug can cause angioedema of the tongue, face, and/or neck that can be life-threatening (especially in patients with hereditary angioedema). However, peripheral edema and livedo reticularis are not associated with this drug.

G) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a first-line agent for hypertension. Common side effects of this drug include electrolyte abnormalities and orthostatic hypotension. Although some patients may experience a hypersensitivity rash, livedo reticularis is not associated with this drug. Moreover, it does not cause peripheral edema. On the contrary, since it is a diuretic, it is sometimes used to treat edema.

H) INCORRECT:

Benztropine is an anticholinergic agent that can be used as a monotherapy in Parkinson patients who are < 65 years old and have resting tremor as the predominant symptom. Since it is an anticholinergic agent, it tends to be avoided in patients > 65 years old, as it is more likely to cause side effects such as urinary retention, constipation, and delirium. However, ankle edema and livedo reticularis are not commonly seen with the use of this drug.
questions.hint: This patient is taking an antiparkinson medication that commonly causes ankle edema and livedo reticularis. In rare cases, it may cause confusion, hallucinations, and nightmares.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of worsening involuntary movement of the left hand. She also reports that it takes her longer than usual to get up from a chair. Her symptoms are worse when she feels stressed at work. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Neurological examination shows difficulty initiating movement and a tremor in the left hand at rest. The tremor decreases when the patient is asked to draw a circle. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clonazepam can be used to treat orthostatic tremor. The average age of onset of orthostatic tremor is 60 years of age, and this patient is 55. However, the typical clinical features of orthostatic tremor are triggered by longer periods of standing; they include tremor of the legs and a subjective sensation of instability. As this condition only affects the legs, it cannot be the cause of this patient's hand tremor.

B) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is used in the treatment of hyperthyroidism, which can manifest with a tremor that increases with stress. However, the tremor is usually symmetric and occurs while holding positions against gravity (e.g., extending the arms in front of the body). Moreover, hyperthyroidism would not explain this patient's bradykinesia. In a patient with hyperthyroidism, other features (e.g., anxiety, hyperreflexia, weight loss, sweating) would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is a drug of choice in the treatment of benign essential tremor. Essential tremor can be exacerbated by stress, as reported by this patient. However, unlike the asymmetric resting tremor seen here, essential tremor is symmetrical, worsens with voluntary movements, and resolves when the patient is completely at rest.

D) INCORRECT:

Antimuscarinic drugs such as trihexyphenidyl or benztropine can be used to treat tremors and rigidity in patients with Parkinson disease. However, this type of drug would not improve bradykinesia, which is seen in this patient. A different drug would therefore be preferred in a patient who has difficulty initiating movements.

E) INCORRECT:

Donepezil is a cholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of various forms of dementia, such as Alzheimer disease, vascular dementia, frontotemporal dementia, and dementia associated with late-stage Parkinson disease. This patient does not yet show signs of cognitive impairment and has only recently begun noticing neurological deficits.

F) CORRECT:

A non-ergot dopamine agonist such as pramipexole or ropinirole is the typical first-line treatment for Parkinson disease in young patients (< 65 years) without cognitive impairment. If symptoms are severe, combination treatment of levodopa with carbidopa and/or a COMT inhibitor (e.g, entacapone) can be initiated. Levodopa is more effective than dopamine agonists. However, levodopa therapy is usually reserved for elderly patients or patients with cognitive impairment.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) or amantadine can be used as monotherapy in patients with minimal symptoms that do not affect quality of life, or as an adjunct with dopamine agonists or levodopa in more severe cases.
questions.hint: Bradykinesia and a unilateral resting tremor (“pill-rolling tremor”) that worsens with stress and improves with voluntary movement are consistent with Parkinson disease.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of a 3-week history of abnormal behavior. His wife reports he has been preoccupied with gambling at the local casino. He becomes restless and irritable when his wife attempts to restrict his gambling. Four months ago, he was diagnosed with Parkinson disease and treatment was initiated. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug that was most likely prescribed for this patient?

choices.text: Selective inhibition of monoamine oxidase B

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbidopa, a DOPA decarboxylase inhibitor, is administered in combination with levodopa to inhibit its peripheral conversion to dopamine. This reduces the side effects of levodopa that result from increased systemic dopamine levels (e.g., postural hypotension, nausea). Carbidopa-levodopa is the preferred first-line therapy in Parkinson disease patients > 65 years of age or younger patients presenting with moderate to severe symptoms. Impulse control disorder, which is seen here, is not associated with carbidopa use.

B) INCORRECT:

Amantadine is thought to increase the bioavailability of dopamine by enhancing presynaptic release and inhibiting reuptake. In addition, amantadine acts as a weak NMDA receptor antagonist. It has some efficacy in treating Parkinson disease, particularly mild symptoms, and resolving akinetic crises. Amantadine is usually well tolerated but side effects include peripheral edema, livedo reticularis, confusion, and hallucinations. Although amantadine is not a direct anticholinergic agent, it also exhibits anticholinergic side effects (dry mouth, urinary retention, and constipation). Recent evidence has suggested that its antiglutamatergic activity can help to treat the impulse control disorders associated with the use of a different class of antiparkinsonian drugs.

C) CORRECT:

Direct dopamine receptor agonists (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole) are the first-line treatment for Parkinson disease patients < 65 years of age. They are, however, associated with the development of impulse control disorders (e.g., compulsive gambling, hypersexuality, excessive spending of money), which occurs in up to 50% of patients with long-term use. This adverse effect is presumably due to decreased neuronal activity in brain areas responsible for impulse and inhibitory control. Risk factors include high doses, long duration of treatment, young age, and male sex. Other common side effects of dopamine agonists include nausea, drowsiness, orthostatic hypotension, confusion, and hallucinations.

Patients may also develop compulsive use of these drugs (termed dopaminergic dysregulation syndrome). A withdrawal syndrome resembling cocaine withdrawal (e.g., anxiety, depression, sweating, nausea, fatigue, and drug craving) may occur if the drug is abruptly discontinued.

DOPA-Decarboxylase (DDC) inhibitors (e.g., carbidopa) decrease the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, which results in reduced peripheral side-effects of L-DOPA. These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore do not reduce dopamine production in the brain nor do they have central side-effects.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.

Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.

NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

D) INCORRECT:

Selective monoamine oxidase B inhibitors (e.g., rasagiline, safinamide, selegiline) reduce dopamine degradation in the brain and are a treatment option for early-stage mild Parkinson disease. Common side effects include nausea, headache, confusion, and hallucinations. Impulse control disorder, which is seen here, has been associated with the use of rasagiline in a few case reports; however, a different group of drugs is more likely to cause this adverse effect.

E) INCORRECT:

Entacapone and tolcapone, which are catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) inhibitors, can prolong the action of levodopa by reducing its degradation. As they are always used in combination with levodopa and carbidopa, COMT inhibitors are effective in patients with a decreasing response to levodopa or a fluctuation in motor symptoms. Common side effects include dyskinesia, hallucinations, confusion, nausea, orthostatic hypotension, diarrhea, and an orange discoloration of the urine. Impulse control disorder, which is seen here, is not associated with this group of drugs.
questions.hint: Pramipexole, a non-ergot alkaloid used in the treatment of Parkinson disease, is known to cause impulse control disorder (e.g., pathological gambling).

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a 4-year history of Parkinson disease comes to the physician for evaluation of his medication. Since his last visit one year ago, he has had increased tremor and bradykinesia up to an hour before his next scheduled dose and sometimes feels like he does not respond to some doses at all. One week ago, he was entirely unable to move for about a minute when he wanted to exit an elevator. The physician prescribes a drug that increases the bioavailability of levodopa by preferentially preventing its peripheral methylation. This patient was most likely prescribed which of the following drugs by the physician?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbidopa is a decarboxylase inhibitor that is often given as a combined levodopa/carbidopa formulation. Although carbidopa increases the bioavailability of levodopa like the drug prescribed by the physician, it acts by decreasing the peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine. Additionally, this reduces the peripheral side effects of levodopa (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, nausea, and vomiting). Carbidopa cannot cross the blood-brain barrier, so it does not negatively affect dopamine production in the brain. Since levodopa/carbidopa is typically the first-line treatment of Parkinson disease in patients > 65 years of age, this patient is likely already receiving this medication.

B) CORRECT:

Entacapone is a peripherally acting COMT inhibitor that reduces the methylation of levodopa and dopamine, thus allowing a more stable and long-lasting plasma concentration of the drug. This results in fewer periods of end-of-dose akinesia and less variability of symptoms during the day. Tolcapone is a centrally acting COMT inhibitor that is used for refractory Parkinson disease.

Motor fluctuations increase during long-term therapy with levodopa because the neurons gradually lose their capacity to store and release dopamine. The severity of symptoms is directly related to the drug dose.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.

Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.

NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

C) INCORRECT:

Ropinirole is a non-ergot dopamine agonist that acts directly at the striatal dopamine receptors. Non-ergot dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole) do not increase the bioavailability of levodopa but are used as first-line treatment of Parkinson in patients under the age of 65 and for treatment of primary restless legs syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Trihexyphenidyl, as well as benztropine, are centrally acting anticholinergic agents that inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, thus decreasing the concentration of ACh. Lowering ACh levels proportionately to dopamine levels improves Parkinson symptoms by reestablishing the balance of ACh sensitivity in the basal ganglia. Trihexyphenidyl does not increase the bioavailability of levodopa but is used as monotherapy in patients under the age of 65 with tremor as the main complaint.

E) INCORRECT:

Amantadine is an NMDA antagonist whose mechanism of action is not yet fully understood. However, it is known to increase the bioavailability of dopamine, not levodopa, by increasing its release and decreasing its reuptake in central presynaptic terminals. Moreover, it may exert central anticholinergic effects. Amantadine is the drug of choice during akinetic crises and can be used for reduction of levodopa-induced dyskinesia as in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Rasagiline, as well as selegiline, are selective MAO-B inhibitors that decrease dopamine degradation in the brain, thus prolonging the effect of dopamine. Rasagiline also appears to have a neuroprotective effect by preventing the free radical damage caused by oxidative metabolism of dopamine. MAO-B inhibitors do not increase the bioavailability of levodopa but can be used as monotherapy in patients with Parkinson under the age of 65 with no significant comorbidities.
questions.hint: The patient is experiencing typical symptoms of long-term treatment with levodopa including a wearing-off effect and increasing motor fluctuations (known as on-off phenomenon and freezing). The drug prescribed by the physician inhibits the enzyme catechol-O-methyltransferase, which may reduce these symptoms by keeping the bioavailability of levodopa more stable.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty walking, clumsiness of her arms and legs, and slurred speech. Physical examination shows masked facies and a slow, shuffling gait. When her ankles are passively flexed, there is involuntary, jerky resistance. Treatment is initiated with a combination of levodopa and carbidopa. The addition of carbidopa is most likely to decrease the risk of which of the following potential adverse drug effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Resting tremor is reduced by L-DOPA therapy. The addition of carbidopa is likely to further reduce the incidence of resting tremor because a combination of these drugs would increase the amount of centrally available dopamine. However, resting tremor is a feature of Parkinson disease and not an adverse effect of L-DOPA therapy.

B) CORRECT:

Following administration, L-DOPA is absorbed into the systemic circulation where it is partially converted to dopamine by the enzyme DOPA decarboxylase. The remaining L-DOPA is then transported across the blood-brain barrier and enters the central nervous system to produce the desired effects. Carbidopa reduces the peripheral (systemic) conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, thereby mitigating the peripheral side effects, including orthostatic hypotension, nausea, and vomiting. Although the combination of carbidopa-levodopa significantly improves drug compliance, many patients still experience some degree of these side effects.

Dopamine agonists (e.g., ropinirole, bromocriptine) bind to the dopamine receptor, mimicking the action of dopamine.

DOPA-Decarboxylase (DDC) inhibitors (e.g., carbidopa) decrease the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, which results in reduced peripheral side-effects of L-DOPA. These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore do not reduce dopamine production in the brain nor do they have central side-effects.

Dopamine precursors (e.g., L-DOPA) are converted by DOPA decarboxylase at the presynaptic neuron resulting in direct dopaminergic effects (especially in D2 receptors).

COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone, tolcapone) inhibits central (tolcapone) or peripheral (entacapone) catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) resulting in the reduced metabolization of dopamine, increase in dopamine effects, a decreased demand for L-DOPA, and a longer therapeutic effect with each dose.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.

Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.

NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

C) INCORRECT:

Urinary retention is a common side effect of anticholinergic medications, such as benztropine, that are used to treat Parkinson disease. However, L-DOPA and carbidopa are not associated with urinary retention.

D) INCORRECT:

Visual hallucinations are a central side effect of L-DOPA therapy and they correlate to the concentration of dopamine in the central nervous system. By decreasing the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, carbidopa increases the fraction of the administered drug that crosses the blood-brain barrier. Therefore, visual hallucinations would be expected to increase rather than decrease.

E) INCORRECT:

Dyskinesia is a central nervous system side effect of L-DOPA that typically occurs with long-term therapy. By decreasing the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, carbidopa increases the fraction of the administered drug that crosses the blood-brain barrier. Therefore, symptoms of dyskinesia would be expected to increase rather than decrease.
questions.hint: This patient has classic symptoms of Parkinson disease (shuffling gait, hypomimia, cogwheel rigidity) and is being treated with levodopa (L-DOPA) and carbidopa. Carbidopa is a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor, which decreases the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine and, thus, increases the amount of L-DOPA that enters the central nervous system.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with Parkinson disease is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after he had a syncopal episode. Over the past two weeks, the patient has felt light-headed upon standing and has noticed that his legs have been swollen. He was started on a medication for early symptoms of Parkinson disease one month ago. Vital signs show blood pressure 114/70 mm Hg when supine and 92/38 mm Hg upon standing. Examination of the lower extremities shows a lacy, purple rash and 2+ pitting edema. Neurologic examination shows an ataxic gait. The physician decreases the dose of medication. The patient is most likely experiencing adverse effects caused by a drug that works through which of the following mechanisms of action?

choices.text: Increased dopamine release from central neurons
Inhibition of acetylcholine activity in the basal ganglia
Selective inhibition of monoamine oxidase type B
Decreased peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine
Inhibition of central methylation of dopamine

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Amantadine increases dopamine release, decreases dopamine reuptake, and inhibits the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor. It can be used as initial short-term monotherapy in patients with mild symptoms of Parkinson disease, mainly for those with prominent tremor. In addition to the side effects seen in this patient, amantadine is associated with anticholinergic-like side effects (e.g., dry mouth, constipation), prolonged QT interval, and psychological disorders (e.g., hallucinations, anxiety).
Image Description:

Dopamine agonists (e.g., ropinirole, bromocriptine) bind to the dopamine receptor, mimicking the action of dopamine.

DOPA-Decarboxylase (DDC) inhibitors (e.g., carbidopa) decrease the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine, which results in reduced peripheral side-effects of L-DOPA. These drugs cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore do not reduce dopamine production in the brain nor do they have central side-effects.

Dopamine precursors (e.g., L-DOPA) are converted by DOPA decarboxylase at the presynaptic neuron resulting in direct dopaminergic effects (especially in D2 receptors).

COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone, tolcapone) inhibits central (tolcapone) or peripheral (entacapone) catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) resulting in the reduced metabolization of dopamine, increase in dopamine effects, a decreased demand for L-DOPA, and a longer therapeutic effect with each dose.

MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) reduce the metabolism of central dopamine by inhibiting the monoamine oxidase B enzyme, which normally breaks down dopamine (and catecholamines) in the brain. This results in a prolonged dopamine effect and reduced demand for L-DOPA.

Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) inhibit excitatory cholinergic neurons, resulting in a proportionately lower concentration of acetylcholine compared to dopamine.

NMDA antagonists (e.g., amantadine) act as antagonists at the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which results in a dopaminergic effect.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of acetylcholine activity in the basal ganglia is the mechanism of action of muscarinic antagonists (e.g., benztropine). Muscarinic antagonists can be used as initial monotherapy in patients with Parkinson disease, particularly in those with a prominent tremor. Although muscarinic antagonists can lead to hypotension, they would not explain this patient's livedo reticularis, peripheral edema, or ataxia. Anticholinergic side effects such as dry mouth, confusion, and constipation would occur instead.

C) INCORRECT:

Selective monoamine oxidase type B (MAO-B) inhibitors (e.g., selegiline) increase dopamine availability by preventing its breakdown. MAO-B inhibitors can be used for short-term monotherapy in the early stages of Parkinson disease. Although patients can experience orthostatic hypotension from MAO-B inhibitor therapy, livedo reticularis and peripheral edema are not typical. Other adverse effects of MAO-B inhibitors include headaches, dizziness, psychological disorders (e.g., hallucinations), and hypertensive crisis (when ingested with foods containing tyramine).

D) INCORRECT:

By decreasing the peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine, carbidopa increases the amount of levodopa that can cross the blood-brain barrier and enter the central nervous system. Carbidopa is only used in combination with levodopa and would not be administered as monotherapy. Furthermore, carbidopa reduces the risk of side effects due to increased peripheral dopamine (e.g., orthostatic hypotension) and would not explain this patient's livedo reticularis, peripheral edema, or ataxia.

E) INCORRECT:

By inhibiting central methylation of dopamine to 3-methoxytyramine, catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) inhibitors (e.g., tolcapone) increase dopamine availability. COMT inhibitors are typically used in combination with carbidopa/levodopa; they should not be used as monotherapy. Although COMT inhibitors can cause orthostatic hypotension, they would not cause this patient's livedo reticularis, peripheral edema, or ataxia.
questions.hint: This patient shows signs of amantadine toxicity, including orthostatic hypotension, livedo reticularis, peripheral edema, and ataxia.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is brought to the office by his wife because of unusual behavior for the past 2 weeks. His wife reports that the patient spent a large sum of money at the local casino and bought a new car without consulting her. He has been sleeping poorly. She says, “This is very unusual for him. Yesterday, he also tried to flirt with my best friend at a birthday party while I was just 5 feet away.” He has hypertension, restless legs syndrome, and allergic rhinitis. His medications are propranolol, ropinirole, and budesonide nasal spray. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. When asked about his mood, the patient replies, “I feel fine. I just had to buy that car; she's such a beauty. I want to get out of here to take her for a ride!” The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The criteria for involuntary hospitalization include danger to oneself, danger to others, and grave disability due to underlying psychiatric illness. Although this patient presents with behavior that is suggestive of psychiatric disease, he does not pose a danger to himself or others, nor is he gravely disabled as a result of his illness.

B) INCORRECT:

Risperidone is a second-generation antipsychotic that is used to treat bipolar disorder, which can manifest with increased goal-directed activity (e.g., increased libido, sudden purchase of a new car), loss of social inhibitions, and decreased sleep. This patient's history, however, suggests a specific cause of his symptoms for which risperidone is not useful. Another course of action is more appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Dopamine agonists (DAs) such as ropinirole may lead to impulse control disorders (ICDs), irrespective of the underlying disease. Patients taking DAs should be aware of this adverse effect and regularly monitored, because ICDs may have debilitating effects on their work and social functioning. If the patient shows signs of ICDs, the dose should be slowly tapered or discontinued until symptoms resolve. Abrupt discontinuation of DAs can lead to dopamine agonist withdrawal syndrome. Although most patients with ICDs due to DA therapy respond well to discontinuation of the medication, ICDs may persist in some patients.

Other adverse effects of DAs include restlessness, nausea, orthostatic hypotension, drowsiness, hallucinations, and psychosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is used in the treatment of some ICDs, such as kleptomania and conduct disorder. This patient's history suggests a specific cause of his ICD for which CBT is not primarily indicated. Another course of action is more appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Clonazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine that is occasionally used as an alternative agent to treat hypomanic or moderate manic episodes, which can also manifest with increased goal-directed activity (e.g., increased libido, sudden purchase of a new car) and/or excessive involvement in risky activities (e.g., gambling). This patient, however, has an ICD, for which treatment with benzodiazepines is ineffective.

F) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine is used in the treatment of gambling disorder, which is a type of ICD. Although this patient has recently spent a lot of money on gambling, he does not meet the criteria for gambling disorder, and other symptoms such as hypersexuality suggest another diagnosis. Furthermore, SSRIs such as fluoxetine can aggravate the symptoms of restless legs syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's impaired behavioral and emotional regulation (e.g., suddenly spending large amounts of money on gambling and shopping, hypersexuality) that significantly conflicts with societal norms and impairs his social functioning is consistent with impulse control disorders (ICDs).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with an 8-year history of Parkinson disease presents for follow-up. She currently takes high-dose, extended-release ropinirole daily, plus carbidopa-levodopa at a dose of three tablets three times a day. She reports having moderate-to-severe involuntary choreiform movements (dyskinesias) after each dose of carbidopa-levodopa, which stop about an hour before the next dose.
Which one of the following changes to this patient’s medication regimen is most appropriate?

choices.text: Increase the dose of extended-release ropinirole
Give smaller doses of the carbidopa-levodopa more frequently

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Replacing carbidopa-levodopa with amantadine is likely to render this patient more profoundly parkinsonian, as this agent is less potent than carbidopa-levodopa and thus unlikely to provide symptomatic benefit in a patient with advanced PD. Amantadine is sometimes added to levodopa because it can help reduce dyskinesias, but it can also lead to confusion in older patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines do not have antiparkinsonian effects and should be avoided in patients with PD.

C) INCORRECT:

Replacing carbidopa-levodopa with trihexyphenidyl is likely to render this patient more profoundly parkinsonian, as this agent is less potent than carbidopa-levodopa and thus unlikely to provide symptomatic benefit in a patient with advanced PD. Trihexyphenidyl is often associated with adverse effects such as sedation or cognitive impairment in older patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing this patient’s dose of ropinirole, a dopamine agonist, will not help with the dyskinesias and may lead to adverse effects.

E) CORRECT:

The primary symptoms of Parkinson disease (PD) result from reduced activity of dopamine-secreting cells. After several years of treatment with levodopa, the effect of a dose may wear off before the next dose is given, leading to so-called motor fluctuations. If the dose is increased in an attempt to extend the duration of effectiveness, the higher dose may increase dyskinesias — the involuntary drug-induced movements that this patient is already experiencing. Giving levodopa in smaller doses at more frequent intervals may help to reduce both motor fluctuations and dyskinesias.

Key learning point: The most straightforward way to reduce motor fluctuations in a patient with Parkinson disease is to aim for a more even distribution of the carbidopa-levodopa dosing.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complete inability to move and incomprehensible speech that developed over 24 hours. His wife reports he has Parkinson disease and takes levodopa/carbidopa and ropinirole for motor symptoms, sertraline for depression, and clozapine for hallucinations attributed to his Parkinson disease treatment. She mentions that 5 days ago, he underwent elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged home after a 2-day stay. His medications were held perioperatively, and upon discharge, he was told to restart them gradually, but he was unsure how to do this correctly and decided to wait until his scheduled follow-up appointment with his neurologist next week. On examination, he is alert but appears rigid and cannot initiate any voluntary movements. His mucous membranes are dry. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 102; R, 18; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F); and oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. Laboratory results show sodium, 145 mEq/L; potassium, 4.2 mEq/L; chloride, 105 mEq/L; bicarbonate, 22 mEq/L; BUN, 38 mg/dL; creatinine, 1.3 mg/dL; glucose, 118 mg/dL; white blood cell count, 9,800/μL; hemoglobin, 13.2 g/dL; and creatine kinase, 90 U/L. What is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malignant hyperthermia occurs within minutes to hours of exposure to volatile anesthetics or succinylcholine. It manifests with early signs including tachycardia, tachypnea, and rigidity, followed by severe hyperthermia (up to 45°C) and evidence of secondary organ damage (e.g., acute kidney injury, rhabdomyolysis). This patient's presentation, 5 days postoperative with only mild hyperthermia and normal creatine kinase, makes malignant hyperthermia unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) typically has an insidious onset over 2–4 weeks after initiation of dopamine blocking agents (e.g., antipsychotic medications) and presents with the constellation of fever, autonomic instability, lead-pipe rigidity, altered mental status, and markedly elevated creatine kinase (often > 1000 U/L). This patient's normal creatine kinase and the temporal relationship to the discontinuation rather than the initiation of medications, including an antipsychotic, make NMS less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Serotonin syndrome has acute onset (within 24 hours) and presents with a classic triad of autonomic dysfunction, neuromuscular excitability (hyperreflexia, myoclonus, clonus), and altered mental status. This patient has akinesia and rigidity rather than the neuromuscular excitability characteristic of serotonin syndrome. Additionally, serotonin syndrome typically occurs with initiation or dose increases of serotonergic medications, not after their discontinuation as occurred in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

While this patient may be at risk for antidepressant discontinuation syndrome due to the recent cessation of sertraline, his clinical presentation suggests a different cause. Antidepressant discontinuation syndrome typically presents with flu-like symptoms, insomnia, nausea, imbalance, sensory disturbances (e.g., paresthesias), and hyperarousal rather than the complete inability to move and severe rigidity seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation with inability to move, incomprehensible speech, severe rigidity, and mild hyperthermia following recent discontinuation of levodopa/carbidopa is most consistent with akinetic crisis. This condition is caused by severe dopamine deficiency following discontinuation of levodopa therapy in patients with Parkinson disease. Signs of dehydration and mild acute kidney injury with an elevated BUN-to-creatinine ratio as seen in this patient are a common complication resulting from inability to maintain adequate oral intake.
